content: The Act titled "Royal Hong Kong Police Anticrime Strategy Act of 1997" outlines the Royal Hong Kong Police Anticrime Strategy. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to law enforcement agencies, including the Attorney General and various federal agencies like the DEA and FBI. The curr_chunk defines terms related to law enforcement agencies, including the Department of the Treasury, the United States Secret Service, and other federal agencies authorized to enforce federal law. It also explains the term "qualified former officer of the Royal Hong Kong Police" as an individual employed by the Royal Hong Kong Police before June 30, 1997, with specific law enforcement responsibilities. The Attorney General and the Secretary of the Treasury will conduct a study on the potential recruitment of qualified former officers of the Royal Hong Kong Police by Federal law enforcement agencies to assist in the prevention, detection, investigation, or prosecution of federal criminal offenses. The Attorney General and the Secretary of the Treasury will conduct a study on potential recruitment of former Royal Hong Kong Police officers by Federal law enforcement agencies for preventing, detecting, investigating, or prosecuting federal criminal offenses. They will consult with the Director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy and include their recommendations in the report submitted to Congress. The report will analyze the benefits of hiring former Royal Hong Kong Police officers by Federal law enforcement agencies to assist in preventing, detecting, and prosecuting federal criminal offenses, including drug trafficking and illegal immigration. The report will assess the potential contributions of former Royal Hong Kong Police officers to Federal law enforcement agencies in combating federal criminal offenses such as drug trafficking, illegal immigration, arms trafficking, and violations of section 1956 of title 18, United States Code. It will also examine the specialized knowledge and capabilities these officers could offer, including translation and linguistic support, and identify any legal or administrative obstacles to their recruitment, hiring, or retention. The report will evaluate the potential benefits of hiring former Royal Hong Kong Police officers by Federal law enforcement agencies to address federal criminal offenses. It will also assess any legal or security barriers and propose recommendations for legislation if needed. Additionally, it will consider potential security concerns and ways to mitigate risks through deployment in support roles. Authorization of Appropriations for fiscal year 1998 and succeeding years to hire qualified former officers of the Royal Hong Kong Police if certified by the Attorney General or Secretary of the Treasury as beneficial to Federal law enforcement. The Attorney General and Secretary of the Treasury can authorize appropriations for hiring up to 100 qualified former officers of the Royal Hong Kong Police to support the Department of Justice for fiscal years 1998-2001. The Attorney General and Secretary of the Treasury can authorize appropriations for hiring up to 100 qualified former officers of the Royal Hong Kong Police to support the activities of the Department of the Treasury.
